events.originalText: The Guinean military engineered a coup d'état, announcing that it planned to rule the country for two years prior to a new presidential election.
events.subtitle: Republic of Guinea Armed Forces
events.headline: Guinean military engineers coup d'état, plans to rule for two years

events.originalText: The Pioneer Helmet, one of only six Anglo-Saxon helmets to be discovered, was first placed on public display.
events.subtitle: Pioneer Helmet
events.headline: Pioneer Helmet displayed for public viewing

events.originalText: About 88 percent of eligible voters in Slovenia voted to secede from the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
events.subtitle: 1990 Slovenian independence referendum
events.headline: Slovenia votes to secede from Yugoslavia with 88% support

events.originalText: An engine fire caused Aeroflot Flight 3519 to crash shortly after takeoff from Krasnoyarsk, USSR, killing all but one of the 111 people on board.
events.subtitle: Aeroflot Flight 3519
events.headline: Aeroflot Flight 3519 crashes after engine fire, one survivor

events.originalText: Tokyo Tower, then the world's tallest freestanding tower, opened.
events.subtitle: Tokyo Tower
events.headline: Tokyo Tower opens as world's tallest freestanding tower

events.originalText: Leading the Australia national cricket team, Ian Craig became the youngest-ever Test cricket captain at the time.
events.subtitle: Australia national cricket team
events.headline: Ian Craig youngest Test cricket captain for Australia

events.originalText: The Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act was enacted, lifting most of the existing common-law restrictions on women in the United Kingdom.
events.subtitle: Sex Disqualification (Removal) Act 1919
events.headline: Sex Disqualification Act lifts restrictions on women in UK

events.originalText: First World War: Allied forces gained a strategic victory at the Battle of Magdhaba on the Sinai Peninsula.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: Allied forces victorious at Battle of Magdhaba in WWI

events.originalText: During a bout of mental illness, Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh (pictured) severed part of his left ear and gave it to a woman in a brothel in Arles, France.
events.subtitle: Mental disorder
events.headline: Vincent van Gogh severs ear during mental illness

events.originalText: Jane Austen's novel Emma was first published.
events.subtitle: Jane Austen
events.headline: Jane Austen's Emma published for the first time

events.originalText: George Washington resigned as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army at the Maryland State House in Annapolis (painting shown).
events.subtitle: George Washington
events.headline: George Washington resigns as commander-in-chief at Maryland State House

events.originalText: American Revolutionary War: American troops, overwhelmed by British reinforcements, retreated from the Battle of Iron Works Hill.
events.subtitle: American Revolutionary War
events.headline: American troops retreat from Battle of Iron Works Hill in Revolutionary War

events.originalText: Yohl Ikʼnal acceded to the throne of the Maya city-state of Palenque.
events.subtitle: Yohl Ikʼnal
events.headline: Yohl Ikʼnal becomes ruler of Palenque in Maya city-state
